design_guidelines.md.content:
# Design Guidelines: T-Mobile Customer Happiness Index Dashboard

## Design Approach: Data Dashboard System

**Selected Approach:** Material Design for Data-Dense Applications with T-Mobile Brand Integration

**Rationale:** This is a real-time monitoring and analytics dashboard requiring clear information hierarchy, consistent data visualization patterns, and efficient scanning for actionable insights. Material Design provides robust components for data-heavy interfaces while allowing T-Mobile brand customization.

**Key Principles:**
- Information density with breathing room
- Real-time data prominence
- Scannable metric hierarchy
- Purposeful T-Mobile magenta accents for critical alerts and primary actions
- Professional, technical aesthetic appropriate for operational dashboards

---

## Core Design Elements

### A. Typography

**Font System:** Inter (via Google Fonts CDN)
- Primary: Inter (400, 500, 600, 700 weights)
- Monospace for metrics: 'Roboto Mono' (400, 500)

**Hierarchy:**
- Dashboard Title: 2.5rem (40px), weight 700
- Section Headers: 1.5rem (24px), weight 600
- Metric Labels: 0.875rem (14px), weight 500, uppercase, letter-spacing 0.05em
- Metric Values: 2rem-3rem (32-48px), weight 600, monospace
- Body Text: 1rem (16px), weight 400
- Small Text/Timestamps: 0.75rem (12px), weight 400
- AI Insights: 0.9375rem (15px), weight 400, line-height 1.6

### B. Layout System

**Spacing Primitives:** Tailwind units of 2, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16
- Component padding: p-4, p-6, p-8
- Section gaps: gap-4, gap-6
- Margin separators: mb-4, mt-8
- Card spacing: p-6 standard, p-8 for primary sections

**Grid Structure:**
- Main container: max-w-screen-2xl mx-auto px-6
- Dashboard grid: 12-column system using CSS Grid
- Responsive breakpoints: md (768px), lg (1024px), xl (1280px), 2xl (1536px)

**Key Layout Zones:**
```
Header: Fixed top navigation (h-16)
Main Content: Grid-based dashboard (3-4 columns on desktop)
  - Left: Live webcam feed + emotion detection (4 cols)
  - Center: Happiness metrics + visualizations (4 cols)
  - Right: AI insights + alerts (4 cols)
  - Full-width: Historical charts and trends
```

**Responsive Behavior:**
- Desktop (lg+): 3-4 column grid layout
- Tablet (md): 2 column grid
- Mobile: Single column stack

---

## C. Component Library

### Navigation & Header
**Top Bar:**
- Height: h-16
- Logo placement: Left-aligned with px-6
- Status indicators: Right-aligned (connection status, last update timestamp)
- Real-time badge: Pulsing indicator showing "LIVE"
- Actions: Export report button, settings icon

### Data Display Components

**Metric Cards:**
- Rounded corners: rounded-xl
- Padding: p-6
- Shadow: shadow-lg
- Structure: Label (small, uppercase) → Value (large, monospace) → Trend indicator (icon + percentage)
- Min height: min-h-32
- Hover: subtle lift effect (shadow-2xl)

**Happiness Score (Hero Metric):**
- Prominent circular gauge or large numerical display
- Size: Occupies 2x2 grid cells
- Central placement with visual weight
- Real-time updating animation (smooth transitions)
- Color-coded segments (via T-Mobile magenta accents)

**Emotion Distribution:**
- Horizontal bar chart or donut chart
- Labels: Happy, Neutral, Frustrated, Angry, Delighted
- Percentage values inline
- Icons for each emotion category
- Live updating with smooth transitions

### Webcam Feed Section
**Live Camera Display:**
- Aspect ratio: 16:9 or 4:3 maintained
- Rounded corners: rounded-lg
- Overlay: Semi-transparent emotion detection box
- Active detection indicator: Glowing border when face detected
- Emotion label: Floating badge showing current detected emotion
- Frame rate indicator: Small text showing FPS
- Padding: p-4 container

**Detection Overlay:**
- Face bounding box with soft glow
- Confidence score display
- Emotion label with icon
- Timestamp of last detection

### AI Insights Panel
**Gemini Analysis Section:**
- Distinct visual treatment (card with gradient border)
- Header: "AI-Generated Insights" with Gemini icon
- Content structure:
  - Key findings (bullet points, icons)
  - Recommendations (numbered list)
  - Root cause analysis (expandable sections)
- Auto-refresh indicator
- Timestamp showing last analysis

**Insight Cards:**
- Compact layout: p-4
- Icon + headline + brief description
- Priority indicator (high/medium/low)
- Expandable for full details

### Alerts & Notifications
**Alert Banner:**
- Full-width positioning below header
- Slide-in animation from top
- Critical alerts: Prominent with icon
- Dismissible: Close button top-right
- Action buttons inline (e.g., "View Details", "Acknowledge")

**Alert Queue:**
- Right sidebar on desktop
- Fixed position: right-0 top-16
- Max width: w-80
- Scrollable list with max-h
- Individual alert items: p-3, mb-2

### Data Visualizations

**Chart Components:**
- Line charts: Emotion trends over time (last hour/day)
- Bar charts: Emotion distribution
- Area charts: Happiness score history
- Gauge/Radial: Current happiness index
- Padding: p-6 for chart containers
- Axis labels: text-xs
- Legends: Bottom or right placement
- Tooltips: Appears on hover with timestamp + value

**Chart Containers:**
- Rounded: rounded-lg
- Min height: min-h-64 for readability
- Responsive sizing based on grid
- Grid lines: Subtle, minimal
- Interactive: Hover states, clickable legends

### Customer Feedback Interface
**Input Section:**
- Card layout with rounded-xl
- Textarea: Multi-line text input with min-h-32
- Character counter: Bottom-right
- Submit button: Full-width or right-aligned
- Recent feedback list: Scrollable with max-h-96

**Feedback Items:**
- Compact cards: p-4
- Structure: Text snippet → Emotion analysis → Timestamp
- Gemini analysis badge: Showing AI sentiment score
- Expandable for full text

### Tables (for historical data)
**Data Tables:**
- Sticky header row
- Zebra striping for rows
- Padding: px-4 py-3 for cells
- Sortable columns with icon indicators
- Pagination: Bottom-center placement
- Row hover: Subtle highlight

---

## D. Animations

**Use Sparingly:**
- Real-time metric updates: Smooth number transitions (duration-300)
- Chart data updates: Gentle easing transitions
- Live indicator: Subtle pulse animation (2s cycle)
- Alert entry: Slide-in from top (duration-500)
- Card hover: Slight lift (transform translateY(-2px))

**Prohibited:**
- Continuous background animations
- Excessive parallax effects
- Distracting decorative animations

---

## Layout Specifications

### Dashboard Grid Layout
**Desktop (lg+):**
```
Row 1: Happiness Score (large) | Emotion Distribution | Alert Summary
Row 2: Webcam Feed | AI Insights Panel | Recent Feedback
Row 3: Historical Trends Chart (full-width)
Row 4: Detailed Metrics (4-column grid of metric cards)
```

**Tablet (md):**
```
2-column layout with stacked sections
Webcam and happiness score prioritized top
```

**Mobile:**
```
Single column stack:
1. Happiness score
2. Live indicator + webcam thumbnail
3. Quick emotion distribution
4. Condensed AI insights
5. Alert list
```

### Spacing & Rhythm
- Section vertical spacing: space-y-6
- Card gaps in grid: gap-6
- Internal card padding: p-6 standard, p-8 for primary content
- Dashboard margins: px-6 py-8
- Consistent 8px base unit rhythm throughout

---

## Images

**No Hero Image:** This is a dashboard application, not a marketing page.

**Image Usage:**
- T-Mobile logo: Header top-left (h-8)
- Emotion icons: Small icons (w-5 h-5) next to emotion labels
- Gemini logo: In AI insights section header (w-6 h-6)
- Status icons: Connection, live indicator, alert icons (w-4 h-4)
- Webcam feed: Live camera capture (primary visual element)

All icons via Heroicons CDN.

---

## Critical Implementation Notes

- **Real-time Updates:** All metrics must show live data with smooth transitions
- **Accessibility:** Maintain WCAG AA standards - sufficient contrast for data readability, keyboard navigation for all interactive elements
- **Performance:** Optimize for real-time data streams - virtual scrolling for long lists
- **Brand Integration:** T-Mobile magenta used purposefully for primary actions, alerts, and accent elements
- **Data Density:** Balance information richness with scannability - use whitespace strategically
- **Professional Aesthetic:** This is an operational dashboard, not consumer-facing - prioritize clarity over visual flair

client/src/components/ui/checkbox.tsx.content:
import * as React from "react"
import * as CheckboxPrimitive from "@radix-ui/react-checkbox"
import { Check } from "lucide-react"

import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"

const Checkbox = React.forwardRef<
  React.ElementRef<typeof CheckboxPrimitive.Root>,
  React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef<typeof CheckboxPrimitive.Root>
>(({ className, ...props }, ref) => (
  <CheckboxPrimitive.Root
    ref={ref}
    className={cn(
      "peer h-4 w-4 shrink-0 rounded-sm border border-primary ring-offset-background focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-2 focus-visible:ring-ring focus-visible:ring-offset-2 disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 data-[state=checked]:bg-primary data-[state=checked]:text-primary-foreground",
      className
    )}
    {...props}
  >
    <CheckboxPrimitive.Indicator
      className={cn("flex items-center justify-center text-current")}
    >
      <Check className="h-4 w-4" />
    </CheckboxPrimitive.Indicator>
  </CheckboxPrimitive.Root>
))
Checkbox.displayName = CheckboxPrimitive.Root.displayName

export { Checkbox }

client/src/components/ui/progress.tsx.content:
"use client"

import * as React from "react"
import * as ProgressPrimitive from "@radix-ui/react-progress"

import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"

const Progress = React.forwardRef<
  React.ElementRef<typeof ProgressPrimitive.Root>,
  React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef<typeof ProgressPrimitive.Root>
>(({ className, value, ...props }, ref) => (
  <ProgressPrimitive.Root
    ref={ref}
    className={cn(
      "relative h-4 w-full overflow-hidden rounded-full bg-secondary",
      className
    )}
    {...props}
  >
    <ProgressPrimitive.Indicator
      className="h-full w-full flex-1 bg-primary transition-all"
      style={{ transform: `translateX(-${100 - (value || 0)}%)` }}
    />
  </ProgressPrimitive.Root>
))
Progress.displayName = ProgressPrimitive.Root.displayName

export { Progress }

client/src/components/ui/slider.tsx.content:
import * as React from "react"
import * as SliderPrimitive from "@radix-ui/react-slider"

import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"

const Slider = React.forwardRef<
  React.ElementRef<typeof SliderPrimitive.Root>,
  React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef<typeof SliderPrimitive.Root>
>(({ className, ...props }, ref) => (
  <SliderPrimitive.Root
    ref={ref}
    className={cn(
      "relative flex w-full touch-none select-none items-center",
      className
    )}
    {...props}
  >
    <SliderPrimitive.Track className="relative h-2 w-full grow overflow-hidden rounded-full bg-secondary">
      <SliderPrimitive.Range className="absolute h-full bg-primary" />
    </SliderPrimitive.Track>
    <SliderPrimitive.Thumb className="block h-5 w-5 rounded-full border-2 border-primary bg-background ring-offset-background transition-colors focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-2 focus-visible:ring-ring focus-visible:ring-offset-2 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:opacity-50" />
  </SliderPrimitive.Root>
))
Slider.displayName = SliderPrimitive.Root.displayName

export { Slider }

VSCODE_SETUP.md.content:
# VSCode Local Setup Guide

This guide explains how to run the T-Mobile Customer Happiness Index project in VSCode without any Replit dependencies.

## Prerequisites

1. **Install Node.js** (v18 or higher)
   - Download from: https://nodejs.org/
   - Verify: `node --version` and `npm --version`

2. **Install Git** (for cloning the repository)
   - Download from: https://git-scm.com/

## Setup Steps

### 1. Clone the Repository
```bash
git clone <your-repo-url>
cd <project-folder>
```

### 2. Install Dependencies
```bash
npm install
```

### 3. Install dotenv (for loading .env files)
```bash
npm install dotenv
```

### 4. Remove Replit-Specific Packages
```bash
npm uninstall @replit/vite-plugin-cartographer @replit/vite-plugin-dev-banner @replit/vite-plugin-runtime-error-modal
```

### 5. Edit `vite.config.ts`

**Open** `vite.config.ts` and **replace the entire file** with this clean version:

```typescript
import { defineConfig } from "vite";
import react from "@vitejs/plugin-react";
import path from "path";

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [
    react(),
  ],
  resolve: {
    alias: {
      "@": path.resolve(import.meta.dirname, "client", "src"),
      "@shared": path.resolve(import.meta.dirname, "shared"),
      "@assets": path.resolve(import.meta.dirname, "attached_assets"),
    },
  },
  root: path.resolve(import.meta.dirname, "client"),
  build: {
    outDir: path.resolve(import.meta.dirname, "dist/public"),
    emptyOutDir: true,
  },
  server: {
    fs: {
      strict: true,
      deny: ["**/.*"],
    },
  },
});
```

**What was removed:**
- `import runtimeErrorOverlay from "@replit/vite-plugin-runtime-error-modal"`
- `runtimeErrorOverlay()` from plugins array
- Dynamic imports for cartographer and dev-banner
- `process.env.REPL_ID` check

### 6. Set Up Environment Variables

Create a `.env` file in the project root:

```bash
# .env
GEMINI_API_KEY=your_gemini_api_key_here
SESSION_SECRET=your_random_session_secret_here
DEMO_MODE=false
```

**Get your API keys:**
- **GEMINI_API_KEY**: Create at https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey
- **SESSION_SECRET**: Generate with `openssl rand -base64 32` or use any random string
- **DEMO_MODE**: Set to `true` for demo (no API calls), `false` for production

### 7. Run the Application

```bash
npm run dev
```

The app will start at **http://localhost:5000** 🚀

## Available Commands

```bash
# Development mode (with hot-reload)
npm run dev

# Type checking
npm run check

# Build for production
npm run build

# Run production build
npm start
```

## System Requirements

- **Node.js**: v18.0.0 or higher
- **npm**: v9.0.0 or higher
- **OS**: Windows, macOS, or Linux
- **RAM**: 2GB minimum (4GB recommended)
- **Webcam**: Required for emotion detection

## Dependencies Overview

### Frontend
- React 18 + TypeScript
- Tailwind CSS + Shadcn UI
- TanStack React Query (data fetching)
- Wouter (routing)
- Recharts (data visualization)

### Backend
- Express.js
- WebSockets (ws)
- Google Gemini API (@google/generative-ai)
- dotenv (environment variable loading)

### Build Tools
- Vite (dev server + bundler)
- tsx (TypeScript execution)
- esbuild (production builds)

## Troubleshooting

### Port Already in Use
If port 5000 is already taken, you can change it in `server/index.ts`:
```typescript
const PORT = process.env.PORT || 5000; // Change 5000 to another port
```

### Webcam Not Working
- Make sure your browser has camera permissions enabled
- Check that no other application is using the webcam
- Try a different browser (Chrome/Edge recommended)

### TypeScript Errors
Run type checking to see all errors:
```bash
npm run check
```

### Gemini API Errors
- Verify your `GEMINI_API_KEY` is correct in `.env`
- Check your API quota at https://aistudio.google.com/
- Free tier has 50 requests/day limit
- Enable `DEMO_MODE=true` for unlimited testing without API calls

## Production Deployment

### Build the Application
```bash
npm run build
```

This creates optimized production files in the `dist` folder.

### Run Production Server
```bash
npm start
```

### Deploy to a Hosting Service
- **Vercel**: Deploy with zero config
- **Netlify**: Works with static site generation
- **Railway**: Full-stack deployment
- **Heroku**: Traditional PaaS deployment

## Differences from Replit Version

**Removed:**
- `@replit/vite-plugin-cartographer` - Dev navigation helper
- `@replit/vite-plugin-dev-banner` - Replit branding banner
- `@replit/vite-plugin-runtime-error-modal` - Runtime error overlay

**These plugins were Replit-specific and not needed for local VSCode development.**

## Need Help?

- Check the main README.md for project architecture details
- Review the code comments in key files:
  - `server/gemini.ts` - AI integration
  - `client/src/pages/Dashboard.tsx` - Main UI
  - `server/routes.ts` - API endpoints

---

**Ready to hack!** 🎉 Your T-Mobile Customer Happiness Index is now running locally in VSCode.

replit.md.content:
# T-Mobile Customer Happiness Index

## Overview
Real-time customer sentiment dashboard using **AI-powered emotion detection** - webcam-based facial emotion detection + text feedback analysis, powered by Google Gemini AI. Built for the T-Mobile hackathon challenge focused on improving customer experience through AI-powered insights.

**Live Demo**: Click "Start Camera" button on the dashboard to begin real-time emotion detection with face tracking.

## Project Purpose
This hackathon project demonstrates how T-Mobile stores can use AI to:
- Track customer satisfaction in real-time through facial expressions
- Analyze text feedback using Gemini's advanced language understanding
- Generate actionable insights to improve customer experience
- Identify patterns and optimize service delivery
- Real-time face tracking for enhanced user engagement

## Target Hackathon Prizes
1. **T-Mobile Customer Experience Challenge**: Real-time happiness tracking for retail environments
2. **Google Gemini API Prize**: AI-powered vision and text analysis for comprehensive sentiment analysis
3. **Workflow Orchestration**: Webcam + Face Tracking → AI Analysis → Dashboard → Insights

## Tech Stack
- **Frontend**: React + TypeScript + Tailwind CSS
- **Backend**: Express.js + Node.js
- **AI Engine**: Google Gemini 2.0 Flash (multi-modal)
- **Real-time**: WebSockets for live updates
- **Storage**: In-memory (suitable for hackathon demo)

## Running Locally in VSCode
For complete instructions on running this project in VSCode without Replit-specific dependencies, see **[VSCODE_SETUP.md](./VSCODE_SETUP.md)**.

Key differences for local development:
- Remove 3 Replit Vite plugins from package.json and vite.config.ts
- Configure environment variables in `.env` file
- All core functionality works identically (webcam, AI, dashboard)

## Key Features

### 1. AI-Powered Emotion Detection
- **Real-Time Multi-Face Tracking**: Dynamic bounding boxes track all detected faces simultaneously using TensorFlow.js BlazeFace model
- **Multiple Person Detection**: Detects and labels multiple people (Face 1, Face 2, etc.) in the same camera view
- **Facial Expression Analysis**: Real-time webcam analysis detecting Happy, Delighted, Neutral, Frustrated, Angry
- **Gemini AI Vision**: Gemini 2.0 Flash analyzes video frames for accurate emotion detection
- **Instant Visual Feedback**: Fast, responsive face tracking with no smoothing delay
- Automatic analysis every 5 seconds for continuous monitoring

### 2. Live Dashboard
- Happiness Index gauge (0-100 score)
- Emotion distribution charts
- Real-time metrics (total interactions, satisfaction rate)
- 24-hour sentiment trend visualization

### 3. AI-Powered Insights
- Gemini analyzes emotion patterns and feedback
- Generates actionable recommendations
- Identifies peak frustration periods
- Suggests operational improvements

### 4. Feedback Analysis
- Text input for customer feedback
- Gemini sentiment classification (Positive/Negative/Mixed)
- Contextual analysis and reasoning
- Historical feedback tracking

### 5. Alert System
- Real-time alerts for negative sentiment spikes
- Priority-based notifications
- Proactive customer service recommendations

## Project Architecture

### Data Flow
```
Webcam → Face Detection + Frame Capture → Gemini Vision API
                                                    ↓
                                          Emotion Detection
                                                    ↓
                                            Storage (In-Memory)
                                                    ↓
                                        WebSocket → Dashboard Updates
                                                    ↓
Text Feedback → Gemini Text API → Sentiment Analysis → Insights Generation
```

### File Structure
- `server/gemini.ts` - Google Gemini API integration (vision + text)
- `server/routes.ts` - REST API endpoints
- `server/storage.ts` - In-memory data storage
- `server/websocket.ts` - Real-time WebSocket connections
- `client/src/pages/Dashboard.tsx` - Main dashboard page
- `client/src/components/WebcamFeed.tsx` - Camera and emotion detection with face tracking
- `client/src/components/GeminiInsights.tsx` - AI-generated recommendations
- `client/src/components/FeedbackInput.tsx` - Text feedback analysis
- `client/src/hooks/useWebcam.ts` - Webcam access and frame capture
- `client/src/hooks/useFaceDetection.ts` - Real-time face tracking with BlazeFace
- `client/src/hooks/useWebSocket.ts` - Real-time data streaming

## API Endpoints

### Emotion Detection
- `POST /api/emotions/analyze` - Analyze webcam frame for emotions
- `GET /api/emotions/stats` - Get emotion distribution statistics
- `GET /api/emotions/recent` - Get recent emotion detections

### Feedback
- `POST /api/feedback` - Submit customer feedback for analysis
- `GET /api/feedback/recent` - Get recent feedback entries

### Insights
- `GET /api/insights` - Get Gemini-generated insights and recommendations

### Metrics
- `GET /api/happiness-score` - Get current happiness index score

## Environment Variables
- `GEMINI_API_KEY` - Google Gemini API key (configured in Replit Secrets)
- `SESSION_SECRET` - Session encryption key
- `DEMO_MODE` - Set to "true" for hackathon demo mode (bypasses Gemini API calls)

## Recent Changes (November 9, 2025)

### Real-Time Face Tracking (NEW!)
- **Dynamic face tracking**: BlazeFace model detects and tracks faces in real-time
- **TensorFlow.js integration**: Uses @tensorflow/tfjs and @tensorflow-models/blazeface
- **Smart bounding box**: Magenta tracking box follows face movement smoothly
- **Automatic scaling**: Properly handles video scaling, letterboxing, and different aspect ratios
- **Visual feedback**: Shows "Face Detected" label or "No face detected" warning
- **Continuous detection**: Uses requestAnimationFrame for smooth, performant tracking
- **Production-ready**: Architect-reviewed coordinate transformation math
- **New hook**: `useFaceDetection` manages model loading and detection loop

### Multiple Face Detection (NEW!)
- **Simultaneous tracking**: System now detects and tracks all faces in camera view at once
- **Multiple person support**: Each detected face gets its own tracking box with numbered labels (Face 1, Face 2, etc.)
- **Instant updates**: Removed smooth transitions for faster, more responsive tracking
- **Array-based architecture**: Hook returns array of face boxes for efficient multi-face rendering
- **Architect-approved**: Clean implementation with no memory leaks or performance issues

### Real-Time Emotion Trends
- **Trend data tracking**: System now groups emotion detections into time buckets
- **Live trend chart**: Displays actual happiness score, positive %, and negative % over time
- **Smart calculations**: Uses weighted averages for accurate sentiment tracking
- **Auto-updating**: Chart refreshes every 10 seconds with new emotion data
- **Production endpoint**: New `/api/trends` endpoint serves real trend data

### Hackathon Demo Mode Implementation
- **Added DEMO_MODE environment variable** for unlimited demonstrations
- **Simulated emotion cycling**: Realistic emotions (Happy, Delighted, Frustrated, Angry, Neutral) with varied confidence
- **Keyword-based sentiment**: Analyzes feedback without API calls
- **Smart insights generation**: Creates contextual recommendations based on emotion patterns
- **Production-safe toggle**: Environment variable prevents accidental demo mode in production

### Initial Implementation
- Set up complete dashboard UI with T-Mobile magenta branding (#E20074)
- Implemented all core components: HappinessGauge, WebcamFeed, EmotionDistribution, MetricCard, GeminiInsights, AlertsList, TrendChart, FeedbackInput
- Created backend API with Gemini integration for vision and text analysis
- Added real-time WebSocket streaming for live emotion updates
- Integrated webcam access and automatic frame capture
- Connected all components to live APIs with proper TypeScript typing

### Technical Decisions
- **In-memory storage**: Suitable for hackathon demo, easy to reset
- **Gemini 2.0 Flash**: Latest experimental model for best performance
- **5-second analysis interval**: Balances API costs with real-time feel
- **AI-powered vision**: Gemini analyzes facial expressions from webcam frames
- **WebSocket updates**: Real-time dashboard without polling overhead
- **Demo mode**: Environment-controlled for safe presentation without API limits

## How to Use

### For Hackathon Demo/Presentation (Unlimited Use)
1. **Enable Demo Mode**: Set environment variable `DEMO_MODE=true` (already configured)
2. Open the dashboard in your browser
3. Click "Start Camera" to enable webcam
4. Allow browser camera permissions
5. **Demo mode will cycle through realistic emotions** automatically
6. Submit text feedback - it will analyze keywords instead of using Gemini
7. View AI-generated insights based on your emotion patterns
8. **Unlimited demonstrations** - no API quota limits!

Demo mode shows varied emotions:
- Happy (85% confidence)
- Delighted (90% confidence)
- Frustrated (70% confidence)
- Angry (75% confidence)
- Neutral (75-80% confidence)

### For Production Mode (Real Gemini API)
1. **Disable Demo Mode**: Remove or set `DEMO_MODE=false` in environment
2. Ensure `GEMINI_API_KEY` is configured in Replit Secrets
3. Follow same steps as demo mode
4. **Real AI analysis** of your facial expressions and feedback
5. Note: Gemini free tier has 50 requests/day limit

### For Development
```bash
# With demo mode (no API calls)
DEMO_MODE=true npm run dev

# With real Gemini API
DEMO_MODE=false npm run dev
```

The application runs on port 5000 with hot-reload enabled.

## User Preferences
- **Branding**: T-Mobile magenta (#E20074) primary color throughout
- **Design**: Modern, professional dashboard aesthetic
- **Real-time**: Emphasis on live updates and immediate feedback
- **AI Transparency**: Show Gemini analysis and confidence scores

## Hackathon Value Proposition

### For T-Mobile Judges
- **Immediate Customer Insights**: Store managers see real-time satisfaction
- **Proactive Service**: Detect frustration before customers complain
- **Data-Driven Decisions**: Optimize staffing based on emotion patterns
- **Competitive Edge**: AI-powered customer experience monitoring

### For Google Gemini Judges
- **Multi-modal Excellence**: Combines vision + text analysis seamlessly
- **Practical Application**: Real business value, not just a tech demo
- **Advanced Prompting**: Structured JSON outputs, reasoning chains
- **Scalable Architecture**: Ready for production deployment

### For Workflow Orchestration Judges
- **Complex Pipeline**: Webcam → AI → Storage → Analytics → Insights
- **Real-time Processing**: WebSocket streaming + async AI calls
- **Error Handling**: Graceful degradation if APIs fail
- **Event-Driven**: Emotion detection triggers downstream analytics

## Future Enhancements
- Multi-camera support for larger stores
- Historical data persistence with PostgreSQL
- Manager alert notifications (SMS/email)
- A/B testing for service improvements
- Integration with T-Mobile CRM systems
- Mobile app for store managers
- Export reports and analytics

## Known Limitations
- In-memory storage (data resets on server restart)
- Requires good lighting for accurate emotion detection
- Single webcam per instance
- No authentication/multi-tenancy (hackathon prototype)

## Testing Notes
- Camera permissions must be granted in browser
- Works best with clear frontal face view
- Gemini API key must be valid and have quota
- WebSocket connection required for real-time updates

---

**Built for**: T-Mobile Hackathon 2025  
**AI Partner**: Google Gemini 2.0 Flash  
**Focus**: Customer Experience + AI Innovation

import * as CollapsiblePrimitive from "@radix-ui/react-collapsible"

const Collapsible = CollapsiblePrimitive.Root

const CollapsibleTrigger = CollapsiblePrimitive.CollapsibleTrigger

const CollapsibleContent = CollapsiblePrimitive.CollapsibleContent

export { Collapsible, CollapsibleTrigger, CollapsibleContent }

client/src/components/ui/scroll-area.tsx.content:
import * as React from "react"
import * as ScrollAreaPrimitive from "@radix-ui/react-scroll-area"

import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"

const ScrollArea = React.forwardRef<
  React.ElementRef<typeof ScrollAreaPrimitive.Root>,
  React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef<typeof ScrollAreaPrimitive.Root>
>(({ className, children, ...props }, ref) => (
  <ScrollAreaPrimitive.Root
    ref={ref}
    className={cn("relative overflow-hidden", className)}
    {...props}
  >
    <ScrollAreaPrimitive.Viewport className="h-full w-full rounded-[inherit]">
      {children}
    </ScrollAreaPrimitive.Viewport>
    <ScrollBar />
    <ScrollAreaPrimitive.Corner />
  </ScrollAreaPrimitive.Root>
))
ScrollArea.displayName = ScrollAreaPrimitive.Root.displayName

const ScrollBar = React.forwardRef<
  React.ElementRef<typeof ScrollAreaPrimitive.ScrollAreaScrollbar>,
  React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef<typeof ScrollAreaPrimitive.ScrollAreaScrollbar>
>(({ className, orientation = "vertical", ...props }, ref) => (
  <ScrollAreaPrimitive.ScrollAreaScrollbar
    ref={ref}
    orientation={orientation}
    className={cn(
      "flex touch-none select-none transition-colors",
      orientation === "vertical" &&
        "h-full w-2.5 border-l border-l-transparent p-[1px]",
      orientation === "horizontal" &&
        "h-2.5 flex-col border-t border-t-transparent p-[1px]",
      className
    )}
    {...props}
  >
    <ScrollAreaPrimitive.ScrollAreaThumb className="relative flex-1 rounded-full bg-border" />
  </ScrollAreaPrimitive.ScrollAreaScrollbar>
))
ScrollBar.displayName = ScrollAreaPrimitive.ScrollAreaScrollbar.displayName

export { ScrollArea, ScrollBar }
